t if he's able to share his own NEAT+Q code.  He is the one 
who created NE=
AT+Q and he has a lot of experience with it.  I'm not

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "crazyhamster03" <mir=
enner@...> wrote:
>
> I'm a Mechanical Engineer and I'm rather new to Neura=
l Networks.  
I'm 
> currently doing research in Q-Learning in the area of =
walking 
> robots.  I ran across NEAT and I'm very interested in using it a=
s a 
> function approximator of my value function. 
> 
> I am doing a singl=
e pendulum balancing upright (much like the 
> mountain-car problem). I am =
currently discreteizing the state-space 
> into a 60x60x3(position,velocity=
,action) table.  This is fine for 2 
> states, but the model I will be impl=
ementing for my walker (3-link 
> pendulum) has 6 states.  I have hopes of =
adapting Matlab NEAT for 
> NEAT+Q.
> 
> I have a few questions on neural n=
ets that I couldn't find a clear 
> answer on by searching through the inte=
rnet.  
> 
> 1) State Features:
>    In the mountain car example there are =
two states: position and 
> velocity.  However, the neural net has 20 input=
s (10 for position, 
> and 10 for velocity).  Am I correct in assuming that=
 each of the 10 
> inputs represents 1/10 of the unit circle for position? =
 I read 
that 
> Neural Networks like inputs in the range of 0 to 1 (why is=
 this?).  
> So if the position is in a certain region, is the input for th=
at 
> feature 1 and 0 for all other state features that represent other 
> =
positions?  Or can it be a fraction between 0 and 1?
> 
> 2) Net Output:
> =
   The mountain car problem had 3 outputs, 1 for each action.  I'm 
> guess=
ing that the output with the highest value corresponded to a 
> discrete ac=
tion.  If NEAT+Q was to approximate a value function 
> however, would the =
outputs still be the 3 actions?
>    In addition, By using the sigmoid 1/(1=
+exp(-4.9x)) the output of 
> each node is forced to be 0 or 1 correct?  In=
 NEAT+Q the output 
error 
> is: r+gamma*Va' which would be used in back-pr=
opagation.  But if 
the 
> output is either a 0 or a 1, how could this be u=
sed to model a 
value 
> function?  Unless the output of the NN is just the=
 sum of inputs 
into 
> the output node.
> 
> 3) Matlab NEAT:
>    Other th=
an number_input_nodes and number_output_nodes in the 
> neat_main.m file, i=
s the entire experiment contained in the 
> xor_experiment_vec.m file?  I'm=
 assuming this is where the Q-
Learning 
> and dynamics simulation would ta=
ke place.
>    Does Matlab NEAT use backpropagation to optimize the weights=
?  I 
> didn't see anywhere in the code where the weights were 
backpropaga=
ted 
> (perhaps I missed something).
> 
> Sorry my message was so long, but=
 I've read through the most of the 
> Stanley/Whiteson/Stone papers, the 17=
-page help file, the 
> readme's contained in the c++ and matlab versions o=
f NEAT, and a 
few 
> unrelated NN websites.  Needless to say I'm new and s=
ort of lost.
